procedure.title: Fire Safety Procedures for Working Machines
procedure.goal: To outline the required maintenance, inspection, and emergency actions to prevent and manage fires in working machines.

steps.note: Perform daily in dusty/fire-hazard conditions, otherwise weekly. Clean after a shift.
Check joints, hoses, and engine compartment. Perform after cleaning.
Perform visual inspection at least annually and document it. Check non-fused cables (battery, alternator, starter) several times a year.
Ensure it cuts power correctly and terminal covers are in place.
Inspect cleanliness of heater and compartment, check for fuel leaks, and test under supervision.
Must be done in a safe outdoor area away from flammable materials. Never leave the machine unattended.
Service hand-held extinguishers and any fixed systems at least annually.

steps.action: move machine to a safe location
steps.note: Move outdoors or away from flammable materials before shutting down.

steps.action: shut down engine and cut power

steps.note: Do not assume the fire is out, even if it appears to be.
Inform supervisor, site manager, and insurance company.

constraints.text: Use authentic replacement parts from known manufacturers.
Machines over 3,000 kg must have at least two 34A233B hand-held fire extinguishers.
Machines in high-risk environments (e.g., timber, peat processing) must have a fixed, automatic fire extinguishing system.
Operators must be trained in the use of fire extinguishers.
Operating manuals must be available in the machine in a language the operator understands.
Delay DPF regeneration if the machine is in a fire-hazard environment (e.g., indoors, underground).
